[[Association of American Universities|AAU]], [[California Collegiate Athletic Association|CCAA]] | motto = ''Fiat lux'' ([[Latin]]) | mottoeng = ''[[Let there be light]]'' | logo = [[Image:UCSD logo.png|220px]] }} The '''University of California, San Diego''', commonly known as '''UCSD''' or '''UC San Diego''', is a [[public university|public]] [[research university]] located in the [[La Jolla]] neighborhood of [[San Diego]], [[California]], [[United States]].[http://ogs.ucsd.edu/About/wlc/Pages/sd.aspx Getting to Know San Diego] UCSD is one of the ten general campuses of the [[University of California]] system and was founded in 1960 near the pre-existing [[Scripps Institution of Oceanography]].{{cite web|url=http://sunsite.berkeley.edu/~ucalhist/general_history/campuses/ucsd/overview.html |title=San Diego: Historical Overview |accessdate=2008-09-17 |publisher=University of California History Digital Archives}} 22,048 undergraduate and 5,073 graduate students enrolled in Fall 2007 and the university awarded 6,802 degrees in 2005/06.{{cite web|url=http://ir.ucsd.edu/Files/Degrees/1961-Present.pdf |format=PDF|title=Degrees Awarded |publisher=University of California, San Diego |accessdate=2008-09-17}} The university is organized into six undergraduate colleges and six graduate divisions and offers 125 undergraduate majors, 52 masters degrees, 51 doctoral programs, and four professional degrees.{{cite web|url=http://ir.ucsd.edu/Files/Fastfacts/0708%20ucsd%20fast%20facts.pdf |format=PDF|title=University of California, San Diego Triton Stats |publisher=University of California, San Diego |accessdate=2008-09-17}} The university is a designated [[sea grant colleges|sea]] and [[space grant colleges|space grant]] institution and has a very high level of research activity. The university operates the [[University of California, San Diego Medical Center|UC San Diego Medical Center]] and is affiliated with several regional research centers, such as the [[Salk Institute for Biological Studies|Salk Institute]], the [[Burnham Institute for Medical Research]], and [[The Scripps Research Institute]]. The university employs 7,566 faculty members including eight [[Nobel Prize|Nobel Laureates]], eight [[MacArthur Fellows Program|MacArthur fellows]], three [[National Medal of Science]] laureates, and one [[Fields Medal|Fields medalist]]. The university was admitted to the [[Association of American Universities]] in 1982.{{cite web|url=http://www.aau.edu/about/article.aspx?id=5476 |title= Association of American Universities: Member Institutions and Years of Admission. Retrieved on 2009-07-16}} UCSD's undergraduate program ranked 8th among public universities according to the 2012 ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' college rankings using indicators such as endowment, giving rates, and the prior high school achievement of incoming students as metrics.{{cite news|url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/rankings/national-universities/top-public|title=Best Colleges: Top Public Schools: National Universities|work=[[U.S. News & World Report]]|accessdate=2011-10-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.stanford.edu/dept/pres-provost/president/speeches/961206gcfallow.html|title=Original USN&WR Ranking Methodology Exposure: An Open Letter|first=Gerhard|last=Casper|publisher=[[Stanford University]]|work=Office of the President}} The university's 19 intercollegiate sports teams are known as the Tritons and participate in the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA's]] [[Division II (NCAA)|Division II]] (DII) level in the [[California Collegiate Athletic Association]]. == History == [[Image:Submersible named Star III in front of Scripps Institution of Oceanography.JPG|thumb|left|Star III, in front of Scripps Institution of Oceanography]] When the [[Regents of the University of California]] originally authorized the San Diego campus in 1956, it was planned as first imagined by [[Roger Revelle]], Director of Scripps, to start as a graduate school of science and engineering comparable in quality to [[California Institute of Technology|Caltech]].{{Cite book | last=Kerr | first=Clark | title=The Gold and the Blue: A Personal Memoir of the University of California, 1949-1967 Volume I: Academic Triumphs | year=2003 | url=http://books.google.com/?id=jMEZ_47vXkAC&pg=RA1-PA254 | pages=248, 254â260 | location=[[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]] | publisher=[[University of California Press]] | accessdate=2009-07-20 | isbn=9780520223677 | ref=harv | postscript=}} Citizens of San Diego supported the idea, voting the same year to transfer to the university {{convert|59|acre|ha}} of mesa land on the coast near the Scripps Institute. The Regents requested an additional gift of {{convert|550|acre|ha}} of undeveloped mesa land northeast of Scripps, as well as {{convert|500|acres|ha}} on the former site of [[Camp Calvin B. Matthews|Camp Matthews]], but Revelle jeopardized the site selection by making public La Jolla's exclusive real estate practices antagonistic to minority racial and religious groups, angering local conservatives as well as UC Regent [[Edwin W. Pauley]]. UC President [[Clark Kerr]] satisfied San Diego city donors by changing the proposed name from University of California, La Jolla, to University of California, San Diego. The city voted in agreement to its part in 1958, and the UC approved construction of the new campus in 1960. Because of the clash with Pauley, Revelle was not made chancellorâ[[Herbert York]], first director of [[Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory]], was designated instead. York worked out the planning of the main campus according to the "[[Oxbridge]]" model, relying on many of Revelle's ideas. UCSD was the first general campus of the UC to be designed "from the top down" in terms of research emphasis. [[John Jay Hopkins]] of [[General Dynamics|General Dynamics Corporation]] donated one million dollars to be used for recruiting a founding faculty.{{cite news|url=http://www.sandiegometro.com/2000/sep/coverstory.html|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080417234035/http://www.sandiegometro.com/2000/sep/coverstory.html|archivedate=2008-04-17|title=Forty Years of UCSD Perspective|last=Gribble|first=Joanne|date=2000-09|work=San Diego Metropolitan |accessdate=2009-07-20}} [[Harold Urey]], Nobel winner in Chemistry, was an early recruit to the faculty in 1958. (Revelle and [[Hans Suess|Suess]] published the first paper on the [[Greenhouse effect]] the year before.) [[Maria Goeppert-Mayer]] was appointed professor of physics in 1960; she later won the Nobel Prize in 1963. The graduate division of the school opened in 1960 with 20 faculty in residence; instruction was offered in the fields of [[physics]], [[biology]], [[chemistry]] and [[earth science]]. Classes initially met in the Scripps Institute. By 1963, new facilities on the mesa been finished for the School of Science and Engineering, and new buildings were under construction for Social Sciences and Humanities. Ten additional faculty in those disciplines were hired, and the whole site was designated the First College of the new campus. York resigned as chancellor in 1963 and was replaced by [[John Semple Galbraith]] in 1964. The campus accepted its first undergraduate class of 181 freshman in 1964, and was designated Revelle College the next year.Stadtman, Verne A. "The University of California, 1868-1968," pages 407-411{{Cite document | last=Stadtman | first=Verne A. | title=The Centennial Record of the University of California | year=1967 | publisher=Office of the Regents of the University of California, Office of the Secretary |url=http://content.cdlib.org/xtf/view?docId=hb4v19n9zb&doc.view=frames&chunk.id=div00852&toc.depth=1&toc.id=div00852&brand=calisphere | accessdate= 2007-08-10 | ref=harv | postscript=}} Second College was also organized in 1964, on the land deeded by the federal government. It was renamed John Muir College in April, 1966.[http://sunsite.berkeley.edu/uchistory/general_history/campuses/ucsd/overview.html University of California History Digital Archives] UCSD Medical school also accepted its first students in 1966. Political theorist [[Herbert Marcuse]] joined the faculty in 1965. A champion of the [[New Left]], he reportedly was the first protestor to occupy the administration building in a demonstration organized by his student, [[Angela Davis]].{{cite news|url=http://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2007/aug/23/bourgeois-marxist/|title=The Bourgeois Marxist|last=Barberella|date=2007-08-23|work=San Diego Reader|accessdate=2009-07-20}} The [[American Legion]] offered to buy out the remainder of Marcuse's contract for $20,000; the Regents censured Chancellor McGill for defending Marcuse on the basis of [[academic freedom]], but further action was averted after local leaders expressed support for Marcuse. [[Richard C. Atkinson]], chancellor from 1980 to 1995, strengthened UCSD's ties with the city of San Diego by encouraging [[technology transfer]] with developing companies, transforming San Diego into a world leader in technology-based industries. Private giving rose from $15 million to nearly $50 million annually, faculty expanded by nearly 50%, and enrollment doubled to about 18,000 students during his chancellorship. In 1995, the quality of UCSD's graduate programs was ranked tenth in the nation by the National Research Council.{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1177/0891242407299426 | volume = 21 | issue = 3 | pages = 203â222 | last = Smilor | first = Raymond | coauthors = Niall O'Donnell, Gregory Stein, Robert S. Welborn | title = The Research University and the Development of High-Technology Centers in the United States | journal = Economic Development Quarterly | accessdate = 2009-07-17 | date = 2007-08-01 | url = http://edq.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/21/3/203 | ref = harv }} UCSD is taking out a $40 million dollar loan against itself to offset $84.2 million in state budget cuts in 2009.{{cite web | title = To soften cuts, UCSD to borrow from itself, $40 million internal loan announced by campus | last = Yang Su | first = Eleanor | work =[[San Diego Union-Tribune]] | date =2009-10-07 | accessdate = 2009-09-20 | url = http://www3.signonsandiego.com/stories/2009/oct/07/soften-cuts-ucsd-borrow-itself/?education&zIndex=178537 }} ===Notable research=== UCSD researchers have made impacts including [[global warming]] research and the discovery of the [[Keeling Curve]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/7120770.stm The Keeling Curve legacy] The widely used computer language, [[UCSD Pascal]] was developed there,[http://invent.ucsd.edu/technology/cases/1995-prior/SD1991-807.shtml UCSD Pascal Copyright][http://ucsdmag.ucsd.edu/magazine/vol1no3/features/pascal.htm UCSD Pascal][http://www.threedee.com/jcm/psystem/index.html The UCSD P-system museum] (which influenced the design of [[Java (programming language)|Java]]), as was the [[Network News Transfer Protocol]] (NNTP).[http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc977 NNTP] Early research activity, notably in the sciences, was integral to shaping the focus and culture of the university. ==Campus== {{wide image|UCSD-Warren Pano.jpg|1090px|
Panorama of [[Earl Warren College]] mall. From left to right: [[Geisel Library]], Engineering Building Unit (EBU) I, the Powell-Focht Bioengineering Building, the Computer Science Building, and EBU II (visible through trees)
}} The university's main campus is located near the Pacific Ocean on {{convert|1200|acre|ha}} of coastal woodland within the city of San Diego's "University Community" planning area.{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiego.gov/planning/community/profiles/university/index.shtml|title=San Diego Community Profile: University|accessdate=2009-07-21 |publisher=City of San Diego}}{{cite web | title = About UCSD | work = Official Web site of the University of California, San Diego | publisher = Regents of the University of California | date = 2009-07-16 | url = http://www.ucsd.edu/explore/about/index.html | accessdate = 2009-07-17}} It is a lab for energy innovation.{{cite web | title = UCSD becoming lab for energy innovation - SignOnSanDiego.com | last = Soto | first = Onell R. | work =[[San Diego Union-Tribune]] | date =2009-09-20 | accessdate = 2009-09-20 | url = http://www3.signonsandiego.com/stories/2009/sep/20/ucsd-becoming-lab-energy-innovation/?education&zIndex=169045 }} === Public art === {{Main|Stuart Collection}} More than a dozen public art projects, part of the [[Stuart Collection]], decorate the campus. Perhaps the most famous of these is the [[Sun God (statue)|Sun God]], a large winged creature located near the Faculty Club. Other Stuart Collection art includes a collection of [[Stonehenge]]-like stone blocks, a large coiling snake path, a table by [[Jenny Holzer]], a building that flashes the names of vices and virtues in bright neon lights, and three metallic [[Eucalyptus]] trees, the Music Tree, the Literary Tree and the Third Tree commonly referred to as the Silent Tree. One of the newest additions to the collection is Tim Hawkinson's giant teddy bear made of six boulders located in between the newly constructed [[Calit2]] buildings. Another notable campus sight are the graffiti tunnels of Mandeville Hall, a series of corridors that have been tagged with [[graffiti]] by generations of students over decades of use. Students in the university's visual arts department also often create temporary public art installations as part of their coursework. The university is also sponsoring a $56,000 [[performance art]] project to develop a sense of community at the sprawling campus. {{Cite news |url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20070218/news_1a18place.html |title='Place': Building a community at UCSD |newspaper=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]] |accessdate=2008-02-07 |last=Steinberg |first=Janice |date=February 18, 2007 |ref=harv |postscript= }} In 2009, local San Diego artist Mario Torero was invited to create a mural called "Chicano Legacy" based on content suggested by UCSD Chicano students.{{cite news |url=http://ucsdnews.ucsd.edu/thisweek/2009/10/19_mural.asp |title=Students Welcomed to Campus by New Mural Celebrating Chicano History |newspaper=This Week @ UCSD |accessdate=2010-01-01 |last=Clark |first=Christine |date=October 19, 2009 }} The mural is a $10,000 digital image on a {{convert|15|by|50|ft|adj=on}} canvas mounted on the exterior of Peterson Hall, which includes representations of [[Cesar Chavez]] and [[Dolores Huerta]] as well as the kiosk structure at [[Chicano Park]].{{cite news |url=http://www3.signonsandiego.com/stories/2009/oct/13/celebration-culture/ |title=A celebration of culture: Chicano history mural to be officially unveiled UCSD campus |newspaper=The San Diego Union-Tribune |accessdate=2010-01-01 |last=Berestein |first=Leslie |date=October 13, 2009 }} ===Special facilities=== UCSD has the 5,000 animal [[Birch Aquarium]] and public museum, the [[San Diego Supercomputer Center]], several large shake facilities including the world record holding [http://nees.ucsd.edu/ Large High Performance Outdoor Shake Table], multiple open ocean [http://shipsked.ucsd.edu research vessels], and a [http://shipsked.ucsd.edu/Marine_Facility sea port]. ==Organization and administration== UCSD is one of the ten general campuses of the [[University of California]] system which is governed by a publicly appointed 26-member [[Regents of the University of California|Board of Regents]] and administered by a president whose office is located in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]], [[California]]. [[Mark Yudof]] became the 19th president of the University system in June 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/aboutuc/governance.html |title=Governance at UC |publisher=University of California |accessdate=2009-07-18}} The board of regents appoint [[chancellor (education)|chancellors]] to serve as the chief administrative officer of each individual general campus. [[Marye Anne Fox]] became the seventh chancellor of UCSD in 2004, succeeding [[Robert C. Dynes]] who served as President of the UC system from 2003 until 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www-chancellor.ucsd.edu/biography.html |title=Governance at UC |publisher=University of California |accessdate=2009-07-18}} Chancellor Fox's total compensation was $401,091 for 2007â2008.{{cite web|url=http://chronicle.com/premium/stats/990/public.php?keyword=marye+anne+fox&radio=Prez&Year=2008&State=&type= |title=Presidents' Pay and Benefits at Public Institutions |publisher=Chronicle of Higher Education |accessdate=2009-07-19}} The chancellor has an immediate staff of eight vice chancellors for academic affairs, research, marine sciences, student affairs, planning, external relations, business affairs, and health sciences.{{cite web|url=http://adminrecords.ucsd.edu/PPM/docs/10-0.pdf |publisher=University of California, San Diego |title=UCSD Administrative Organization Chart |accessdate=2009-07-18}} The university operates on an [[academic quarter (year division)|academic quarter system]] with three primary academic quarters beginning in late September and ending in mid June.{{Harvnb|Catalog|2010|p=5}} ===Endowment=== UCSD has at least two distinct endowments; one controlled by the Regents and another controlled by a privately appointed non-profit corporation called the UC San Diego Foundation.{{cite web|url=http://ucsdfoundation.ucsd.edu/about_us.asp |title=About UC San Diego Foundation |publisher=UC San Diego Foundation |accessdate=2009-07-18}} In 2008, the foundation received $121.8 million in support and managed assets worth $520.7 million in total.{{cite web|url=http://www-er.ucsd.edu/foundationDir/pdf/UCSDFoundation2007-2008.pdf |publisher=UC San Diego Foundation |title=2008 Financial Statement |accessdate=2009-07-18}} In 2007, UCSD became the first university in the western region to top $1 billion in their eight-year fundraising campaign.{{cite web|url=http://ucsdnews.ucsd.edu/newsrel/general/06-081BillionFundraisingLM-.asp |title=UC San Diego Becomes Region's First University to Top $1 Billion in a Fundraising Campaign |publisher=Ucsdnews.ucsd.edu |date= |accessdate=2009-07-16}} ===Student government=== The campus's undergraduate population is represented by a formal [[student government]], known as the Associated Students (ASUCSD) which was founded on 16 December 1964.{{cite web|url=http://as.ucsd.edu |title=Associated Students of UCSD |publisher=As.ucsd.edu |date=2009-06-08 |accessdate=2009-07-16}}ASUCSD Minutes, 16 December 1964 By a student referendum it was abolished in 1972 and later reestablished in 1977.ASUCSD Minutes, 24 May 1977 In 1986, the ASUCSD passed a non-binding resolution calling on the University of California to [[Divestment from South Africa|divest]] from its investments in [[South Africa]] due to the South African governmentâs institutionalized system of [[apartheid]]. The UC subsequently divested from such holdings later that year, a move [[Nelson Mandela]] later pointed to as a catalyst to ending white-minority rule in the country.[https://www.msu.edu/~divest/apartheid.html|South African Apartheid] Each college has its own [[student council]] as well.{{cite web | title = FAQ's about UCSD's Six Colleges | work = Official Web site of the University of California, San Diego | publisher = Regents of the University of California | date = 2009-07-15 | url = http://www.ucsd.edu/prospective-students/undergraduate-college-system/faqs.html#select | accessdate = 2009-07-17}}{{dead link|date=March 2010}} The campus's graduate population is represented by the Graduate Student Association (GSA).{{cite web|url=http://gsa.ucsd.edu |title=UCSD Graduate Student Association |publisher=Gsa.ucsd.edu |date= |accessdate=2009-07-16}} The Association's membership comprises representatives from each of the graduate departments. The number of representatives is proportional to the number of graduate students within that particular department. Additionally, graduate students who serve as teaching or research assistants are represented by the UC-wide union of Academic Student Employees, [[UAW]] Local 2865. == Academics == [[Image:Geisel library.jpg|thumb|UCSD's distinctive [[Geisel Library]], named for Theodor Seuss Geisel ("[[Dr. Seuss]]") and featured in the University's logo.[http://libraries.ucsd.edu/about/see-also/ucsd-libraries-fact-sheet.html UCSD Libraries Fact Sheet - UCSD Libraries]]] {{Infobox US university ranking | GUR = 20 | USNWR_NU = 37 | USNWR_Bus = | USNWR_Law = | USNWR_Medr = 15 | USNWR_Medc = 26 | USNWR_Eng = 12 | USNWR_Political Science = 7 | USNWR_Ed = | ARWU_W = 14 | ARWU_N = 12 | ARWU_SCI = 19 | ARWU_ENG = 9 | ARWU_LIFE = 14 | ARWU_MED = 25 | ARWU_SOC = 24 | Newsweek = | THES_W = 32 | THES_N = 24 | Forbes = 139 | Wamo_NU = 1 | QS_W = 77 | PR_EE = }} UCSD is a large, primarily residential research university.{{cite web|url=http://www.carnegiefoundation.org/classifications/sub.asp?key=748&subkey=13415&start=782 |title=Institutions: University of California-San Diego |publisher=The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching |accessdate=2008-09-17}} The university is accredited by the [[Western Association of Schools and Colleges]].{{Harvnb|Catalog|2010|p=8}}{{cite web|url=http://accreditation.ucsd.edu/ |title=Accreditation |publisher=University of California, San Diego |accessdate=2009-07-18}} UCSD granted 5,337 bachelors degrees, 894 masters degrees, 488 doctorate degrees, and 125 medical degrees in 2007-2008.{{cite web|url=http://studentresearch.ucsd.edu/sriweb/degrees/degsumm.pdf |title=Degrees Conferred: All Degree Types |publisher=Student Research and Information, Student Affairs |accessdate=2009-07-18}} UCSD's comprehensive doctoral program has high undergraduate degree coexistence as well as professional programs in business, medicine, and pharmacy. UCSD's graduate division and professional schools include the [[Scripps Institution of Oceanography]], [[University of California at San Diego School of Medicine|School of Medicine]], [[Institute of Engineering in Medicine]], [[Graduate School of International Relations and Pacific Studies]], [[Jacobs School of Engineering]], [[Rady School of Management]], and [[Skaggs School of Pharmacy]]. The university offers 52 masters programs, 51 doctoral programs, 4 professional programs, and 11 joint doctoral programs with [[San Diego State University]] and other UC campuses. UCSD has noted graduate programs in biological sciences and medicine,{{cite web|url=http://www.arwu.org/ARWUFIELD2009MED.jsp|title=Academic Ranking of World Universities in Clinical Medicine and Pharmacy - 2009|year=2009 |publisher=Center for World-Class Universities and the Institute of Higher Education of Shanghai Jiao Tong University | location=Shanghai, China |accessdate=2009-11-22}}{{dead link|date=March 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-medical-schools/primary-care-rankings |work=America's Best Graduate Schools | title=Best Medical Schools: Primary Care Rankings |publisher=U.S. News & World Report |year=2009 |accessdate=2009-05-18}} economics, social and behavioral sciences, and physics. ===Rankings=== The University of California, San Diego is currently ranked 15th in the world by the [[Academic Ranking of World Universities]]. The 2012 edition of [[U.S. News & World Report]] ranked UC San Diego as the 37th best university in the nation, and the 8th best public university in the United States.[http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/los-angeles-ca/ucla-1315 Rankingsandreviews.com] UCSD is consistently ranked high in other [[college and university rankings]]. http://www.ucop.edu/news/profiles/ucsd.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2007-07-17}}{{cite news|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=990DE4D7133BF937A15750C0A961958260|title=An Information Revolution Revives Its Economy |last=Markoff|first=John|date=1997-03-24|work=New York Times|accessdate=2008-08-03}} ''Science Watch'' ranked UCSD 1st in [[social psychology]],{{cite web|url=http://sciencewatch.com/dr/sci/11/apr3-11_1/|title=Social Psychology: High-Impact U.S. Institutions, 2005-09|publisher=Thomson Reuters: Science Watch}} 2nd in [[oceanography]],{{cite web|url=http://sciencewatch.com/dr/sci/10/jan10-10_1/|title=Oceanography: Most Prolific U.S. Institutions, 2004-08|publisher=Thomson Reuters: Science Watch}} 3rd in [[international relations]],{{cite web|url=http://sciencewatch.com/dr/sci/09/aug2-09_1/|title=International Relations: High-Impact U.S. Institutions, 2004-08|publisher=Thomson Reuters: Science Watch}} 5th in [[molecular biology]] and [[genetics]],{{cite web|url=http://science.thomsonreuters.com/press/2008/8438330/|title=Top Ten Molecular Biology/Genetics Institutions Ranked by Citations, 2002-2006|publisher=Thomson Reuters: Engineering 1997-2007|publisher=Thomson Reuters: Science Watch}} and 18th in [[Neuroscience]] and [[Behavior]]{{cite web|url=http://sciencewatch.com/dr/sci/09/apr26-09_1D/|title=Institution Rankings in Neuroscience & Behavior, 1998-2008|publisher=Thomson Reuters: Science Watch}} using non-survey, quantitative based metrics to determine research impact. UCSD also counts among its research centers the [[Scripps Institution of Oceanography]], the [[San Diego Supercomputer Center]], the [[California Institute for Telecommunications and Information Technology]], and the Center for US-Mexican Studies. {{Cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2005/11/05/arts/05lab.html |title=Researchers Look to Create a Synthesis of Art and Science for the 21st century - |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=2008-02-03 |last=Markhoff |first=John |date=November 5, 2005 |ref=harv |postscript= }} ===Residential colleges=== UCSD's undergraduate division is organized into six [[residential college]]s. The system is modeled on the residential systems at [[Colleges of the University of Oxford|Oxford]] and [[List of colleges of the University of Cambridge|Cambridge]]. They each set their own general-education requirements as well as having their own administrative and advising staff and granting unique degrees and separate commencement ceremonies.{{Harvnb|Catalog|2010|p=9}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ucsd.edu/current-students/academics/commencement/ |title=Commencement |publisher=Ucsd.edu |date= |accessdate=2009-07-16}} In chronological order by date of foundation, the six colleges are: #[[Revelle College]], founded in 1964 as First College, emphasizes a "Renaissance education" through the Humanities sequence which integrates history, literature, and philosophy. It has highly structured requirements. #[[John Muir College]], founded in 1967 as Second College, emphasizes a "spirit of self-sufficiency and individual choice" and offers loosely structured general-education requirements. #[[Thurgood Marshall College]], founded in 1970 as Third College, emphasizes "scholarship, social responsibility and the belief that a liberal arts education must include an understanding of one's role in society". #[[Earl Warren College]], founded in 1974 as Fourth College, requires students to pursue a major of their choice while also requiring two "programs of concentration" in disciplines unrelated to each other and to their major "toward a life in balance". #[[Eleanor Roosevelt College]], founded in 1988 as Fifth College, which focuses its core education program on a cross-cultural interdisciplinary course sequence entitled "Making of the Modern World", has a foreign language requirement, and encourages studying abroad. #[[Sixth College]], founded in 2002 with a focus on "historical and philosophical connections among culture, art and technology." [[Image:Center Hall Front, UCSD.JPG|thumb|left|Center Hall, a lecture hall near the center of campus]] Students affiliate with a college based upon its particular philosophy and environment as majors are not exclusive to specific colleges.{{Harvnb|Catalog|2010|p=12}} John Muir and Earl Warren enroll the largest number of undergraduate students followed by Thurgood Marshall, Revelle, Eleanor Roosevelt, and Sixth.{{cite web|url=http://studentresearch.ucsd.edu/sriweb/enroll/ugcoll.pdf |title=Undergraduates by College |publisher=Student Research and Information, Student Affairs |accessdate=2009-07-18}} Each undergraduate college sets the requirements for awarding provost's honors and honors at graduation in addition to departmental honors and [[Phi Beta Kappa Society|Phi Beta Kappa]] honors. === Extension === UCSD Extension is the continuing education and public program branch of the university.{{cite web | title = UC San Diego Extension - Catalog Fall 2009 | publisher = UC San Diego, Extension | date = 2009-08 | url = http://extension.ucsd.edu/pdf/student/catalog/front.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2009-07-17}} Approximately 50,000 enrolles per year are educated in the university's extension program. The Extension provides over 90 certificate programs and over 12 specialized study programs. Most courses are held evenings and weekends for the convenience to working adults on the main campus or at one of three off campus locations:the Extension Sorrento Mesa Center, the Extension Rancho Bernardo Center, and the Extension Mission Valley Center. The Extension program also includes online only classes. The UCSD Extension program is not affiliated with the UC Cooperative Extension program.{{cite web|url=http://ucanr.org/delivers/categories.cfm|title=UC Delivers|publisher=University of California|accessdate=2010=03-09}} === Charter school === The [[Preuss School]] is a [[charter school]] established on the UCSD campus in 1999 to provide an intensive college preparatory curriculum for [[low-income]] students from the greater [[San Diego]] area.{{cite web|url=http://preuss.ucsd.edu/about/ |title=About The Preuss School UCSD |publisher=Preuss.ucsd.edu |date= |accessdate=2009-07-16}} The Preuss school has been ranked as one of the top ten best high schools in the United States by ''US News & World Report.''{{cite web|url=http://www.usnews.com/articles/education/high-schools/2007/11/29/top-charter-schools.html|title=Best High Schools: Top Charter Schools|publisher=US News & World Report|date=2007-11-29|accessdate=2008-03-24}} == Admissions and enrollment== {| style="text-align:center; float:right; font-size:85%; margin-left:2em" align="center" class="wikitable" |+ ''Ethnic enrollment, Fall 2009{{cite web|url=http://studentresearch.ucsd.edu/sriweb/enroll/ugethnic.pdf|title=Undergraduates by ethnicity|work=Total Undergraduate Enrollment Statistics|publisher=Student Research & Information, University of California, San Diego|accessdate=2009-07-22}}'' ! [[Ethnicity]] !! Undergraduate |- ! [[African American]] | 2% |- ! [[Asian American]] | 48% |- ! [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Hispanic American]] | 13% |- ! [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] | 0% |- ! [[Caucasian American]] | 26% |- ! Unreported/unknown | 10% |} UCSD received 48,114 freshmen applicants for the Fall 2010, and admitted 38.1%.{{cite web | title = Introducing the University | publisher = Student Affairs, Office of the President, University of California | date = 2010-04 | url = http://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/admissions/campuses/files/sandiego.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2009-07-17}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Admitted students attained a mean weighted high school [[Academic grading in the United States#Grade point average|GPA]] of 4.07 and average [[SAT]] score of 1980 .{{cite web |url=http://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/admissions/ITU.pdf |title=Introducing the university |format=PDF}} The average ACT Composite Score is 29. 31% of admitted students receive federal [[Pell Grant]]s.{{Cite news | title=Economic Diversity Among All National Universities | url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/usnews/edu/college/rankings/brief/natudoc_ecodiv_brief.php | archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080101134424/http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/usnews/edu/college/rankings/brief/natudoc_ecodiv_brief.php | archivedate=2008-01-01 | newspaper=[[U.S. News & World Report]]| accessdate= 2007-08-10 | ref=harv | postscript=}} According to the 2010 U.S News and World Report, students applying to UCSD are also most likely to apply to [[UC Berkeley]], [[Stanford University]], and [[Harvard University]] for matriculation [http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/university-of-californiasan-diego-1317]. The four year, full-time undergraduate program comprises the majority of enrollments at the university. The university offers 125 bachelors degree programs organized into six disciplinary divisions: Arts, Humanities, Engineering, Science/Math, Biological Sciences, and Social Sciences.{{cite web|url=http://ir.ucsd.edu/Files/Fastfacts/0708%20ucsd%20fast%20facts.pdf |title=University of California, San Diego Trtiton States 2007-2008 |publisher=Institutional Research, University of California, San Diego |accessdate=2009-07-18}} 38% of undergraduates major in the social sciences, followed by 25% in biological sciences, 18% in engineering, 8% in sciences and math, 4% in humanities, and 3% in the arts.{{cite web|url=http://studentresearch.ucsd.edu/sriweb/enroll/ugdisc.pdf |title=Undergraduate Enrollment by Major Field of Study |publisher=Student Research and Information, Student Affairs |accessdate=2010-09-06}} Each undergraduate colleges sets its own general education requirements (GEs) for graduation in addition to the specific requirements of majors set by individual departments and programs.{{Harvnb|Catalog|2010|pp=16â31}}{{Harvnb|Catalog|2010|p=55}} Graduate admissions are largely centralized through the Office of Graduate Studies. However, the [[Rady School of Management]], [[Scripps Institution of Oceanography]], and the [[Graduate School of International Relations and Pacific Studies]] (IR/PS) handle their own admissions. In 2009, UCSD mistakenly sent Admit Day welcome emails to all its 47,000 freshmen applicants, instead of just the 17,000 who had been admitted.NBC San Diego News. [http://www.nbcsandiego.com/news/local/Youre-Out-Youre-In-No-Youre-Out.html ''Oops! UCSD Sends Acceptance E-mail to Wrong List''] However, school officials quickly realized the mistake and sent an apology email within two hours.{{cite web|last=Holland |first=Gale |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-ucsd-reject1-2009apr01,0,7943711.story |title=UC San Diego admissions gaffe dashes students' hopes - again - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Latimes.com |date=2009-04-01 |accessdate=2009-07-16}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ucsdguardian.org/news/campus-e-mail-mistakenly-welcomes-all-applicants-1.1640689 |title=The Guardian - Campus E-Mail Mistakenly Welcomes All Applicants |publisher=Ucsdguardian.org |date=2009-04-02 |accessdate=2009-07-16}}{{dead link|date=March 2010}} == Student life == [[Image:Price Center, UCSD.jpg|thumb|[[Price Center]]]] The main student hub is the [[Price Center]] located in the center of campus, just south of [[Geisel Library]]. The Price Center offers a variety of services, places, and spaces, including restaurants, the central bookstore, movie theater, and various student organizations. In the Spring of 2003, a Student Referendum was passed to expand the Price Center to nearly double the original size. The [[Price Center]] East expansion was officially opened to the public on May 19, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://ucsdnews.ucsd.edu/thisweek/2008/05/19_pce-launch.asp |title=Campus Celebrates Opening of Price Center Expansion with Launch Party |publisher=Ucsdnews.ucsd.edu |date=2008-05-19 |accessdate=2009-07-16}} There are also three campus centers that cultivate a sense of community among faculty, staff, and students: the [[multiculturalism|Cross-Cultural]] Center, the [[Gender|Women's Center]], and the [[LGBT]] Resource Center. UCSD was the last UC campus to have such centers. All three centers, especially the Cross-Cultural Center that was created first, were founded in the mid-1990s and were the result of student movements that demanded change despite opposition by the campus administration.{{cite web|url=http://ccc.ucsd.edu/About.asp |title=UCSD :: Cross-Cultural Center |publisher=Ccc.ucsd.edu |date= |accessdate=2009-07-16}} There is a music venue on the campus grounds of some fame called the [[ChÃ© CafÃ©]], a collective organization serving multiple functions as an underground music venue, vegan food collective, center for grassroots organizations such as [[Food Not Bombs]], and similar groups and activities.[http://checafe.ucsd.edu/about.html ChÃ© CafÃ© Collective] Prominent local San Diego bands such as [[The Locust]] and [[Pinback]], and national tours such as [[Mates of State]] and [[The Dillinger Escape Plan]] have given the [[ChÃ© CafÃ©]] some fame and praise as a radical vegan collective despite its small size (it fits a few hundred people) and limited sound equipment. ===International House=== International House is home to about 400 students from more than thirty countries.{{cn|date=April 2011}} The I-House community provides a social atmosphere where opportunities for significant cross-cultural exchange between American and international students is plentiful. International learning is fostered through formal programs including current affairs discussions, cultural nights, and a community newsletter. Upper-division undergraduates from all six colleges, graduate students, faculty, and researchers are eligible to live in International House, located in the Eleanor Roosevelt College townhouses. Demand is very high for this special program and there is a waitlist each quarter. Spaces in International House are not guaranteed and admission requires a separate application.[http://hdh.ucsd.edu/housing/location.asp UC San Diego Housing - The Six Colleges and La Jolla Living] ===Events and traditions=== [[Image:Watermelon Drop UCSD.jpg|left|thumb|The June 2007 Watermelon Drop, an annual tradition at Revelle College]] The Associated Students also coordinates a wide variety of concerts and events during the year, including All Campus Dance, Bear Gardens, Loft Events, and the Sun God Festival.{{cite web|url=http://concerts.ucsd.edu/pages/about |title=Concerts + Events :: Associated Students :: About |publisher=Concerts.ucsd.edu |date= |accessdate=2009-07-16}}{{dead link|date=March 2010}} The [[Sun God Festival]], named after the [[Sun God (statue)|statue]] created by [[art]]ist [[Niki de Saint Phalle]], is the best-known of the festivals. The festival has grown in its 28 year history into a 20,000 person event. The day consists of student org booths and performers, as well as an eclectic mix of musical acts across 3 stages. Two other popular campus events include the Pumpkin Drop and the Watermelon Drop, which take place during [[Halloween]] and at the end of the third (Spring) [[academic quarter (year division)|academic quarter]], respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.ucsd.edu/prospective-students/undergraduate-college-system/college-traditions.html |title=College Traditions |publisher=Ucsd.edu |date= |accessdate=2009-07-16}}{{dead link|date=March 2010}} The Watermelon Drop is one of the campus's oldest traditions, famously originating in 1965 from a physics exam question centering on the velocity on impact of a dropped object. A group of intrigued students pursued that line of thought by dropping a watermelon from the top floor of Revelle's Urey Hall to measure the size of the resulting splat. A variety of events surround the Watermelon Drop, including a pageant where an occasionally male but generally female "Watermelon Queen" is elected. In 1979 the Queen rode to Urey Hall in a yellow VW Bug with a cut-off top owned by the winner that year, Bill Clabby. The Pumpkin Drop is a similar event celebrated by the dropping of a large, candy-filled pumpkin from 11-story Tioga Hall, the tallest residential building on the Muir college campus. ===Student media=== {{see also|UCSD TV}} The campus newspaper, operated independent of student funds, is the ''[[UCSD Guardian]]''. The campus also hosts a small independent radio station, [[KSDT Radio|KSDT]], which no longer broadcasts over the airwaves, but still operates online. One of the more controversial aspects of student life at UCSD is the student-run comedy paper, ''[[The Koala]]'', a satirical paper often criticized for its provocative articles and drawings, which is also funded by the A.S.[http://www.thefire.org/index.php/article/72.html FIRE - Student Humor Magazine Prosecuted for Parody at UCSD: University Decision Expected This Week] In 2005, the student government made national news over a controversy regarding [[pornography]] broadcast over the A.S.-funded [[television]] station, SRTV, by members of ''The Koala''. More controversy was generated by the program [[Live Hot Puppet Chat]], a midnight sex-advice puppet show also broadcast on SRTV. In February 2010, members of ''[[The Koala]]'', on their Student Run Television program "Koala TV" publicly supported the "Compton Cookout", a controversial off-campus party mocking Black History Month that included UCSD fraternity members among the organizers.{{Cite news| last = Gordon| first = Larry| title = UC San Diego condemns student party mocking Black History Month| newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date = February 18, 2010| url = http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-ucsd18-2010feb18,0,5698009.story | accessdate = March 29, 2010}} ==Athletics== [[File:Ucsdtriton.jpg|right|thumb|Athletic mascot, the [[Triton (mythology)|Triton]]]] {{Main|UCSD Tritons}} UCSD offers student participation in a wide range of sports including [[swimming (sport)|swimming]], [[water polo]], [[Association football|soccer]], [[volleyball]], [[Rowing (sport)|crew]], [[track and field athletics]], [[fencing]], [[basketball]], [[golf]], [[cross country running|cross country]], [[softball]], [[baseball]], and [[tennis]]. UCSD participates at the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA's]] [[Division II (NCAA)|Division II]] (DII) level in the [[California Collegiate Athletic Association]], although water polo, fencing, and men's volleyball compete at the [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] level. Before joining DII in 2000, the school participated at the [[Division III (NCAA)|Division III]] level and won numerous national championships. {{Cite news |url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/sports/drooz/20021028drooz.html |title=Giving it the old college Triton |newspaper=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]] |accessdate=2008-02-25 |last=Drooz |first=Alan |date=2002-11-04 |ref=harv |postscript= }} UCSD does not have an NCAA football team. Until the 2007-2008 school year, UCSD was the only DII school that did not offer athletic [[scholarship]]s. In 2005, the NCAA created a rule that made it mandatory for DII programs to award athletic grants; a measure was proposed to begin offering $500 "grants-in-aid" to all 600 intercollegiate athletes in order to meet this requirement. In February 2007, a student [[referendum]] was passed with the largest vote in UCSD history, authorizing a $329 annual student fee to fund a raise in coaches' salaries, hire more trainers and provide all athletes with a $500 scholarship.{{cite news|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20070203/news_7m3ucsd.html|title=Athletic fee hike approved at UCSD|last=Yang Su|first=Elinor|date=2007-02-03|work=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]]|accessdate=2009-07-22}} In 2006-2007, UCSD's best season since moving to DII, 19 of 23 athletic programs qualified for post-season competition, including 17 to the NCAA Championships. Eight of those teams finished in the top-5 in the nation.{{cite web|url=http://www.ucsdtritons.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=5800&ATCLID=921992 |title=Earl Edwards Named the NACDA Division II West Region Athletic Director of the Year - UCSDTritons.comâOfficial Web Site of UC San Diego Athletics |publisher=Ucsdtritons.com |date=2005-09-02 |accessdate=2009-07-16}} UCSD fields a number of [[sports club|club sports]] teams. The UCSD [[surfing]] team has won the national title six times and is consistently rated one of the best surfing programs in the nation.{{cite web|last=Clark |first=Christine |url=http://ucsdnews.ucsd.edu/newsrel/general/11-08UCSDTopSurfing.asp |title=UC San Diego a Top Surfing School |publisher=Ucsdnews.ucsd.edu |date=2008-11-19 |accessdate=2009-07-16}} The UCSD [[triathlon]] team is continually one of the top triathlon teams in the nation. In 2008, the women's triathlon team won the US collegiate national championship and UCSD athlete Amanda Felder was the Overall Nation Champion.{{cite web|url=http://recadmin.ucsd.edu/sports/teams/triathlon/overview.php |title=UC San Diego Recreation - Sports Clubs :: Triathlon |publisher=Recadmin.ucsd.edu |date=2007-11-21 |accessdate=2009-07-16}} UCSD also has sport clubs in [[badminton]], [[cycling]], [[dancesport]], [[dance]] team, [[equestrianism|equestrian]], [[ice hockey]], [[lacrosse]], [[roller hockey]], [[rugby union]], [[sailing]], [[Association football|soccer]], [[snow skiing]], [[table tennis]], [[ultimate (sport)|ultimate]], [[volleyball]], [[water polo]], and [[waterskiing]].{{cite web | title = Sports Clubs | work = UC San Diego Recreation | publisher = Regents of the University of California | date = | url = http://recadmin.ucsd.edu/sports/ | accessdate = 2009-07-17}} The National Collegiate Scouting Association (NCSA) 2008 Collegiate Power Rankings{{cite web|url=http://www.ncsasports.org/recruiting-tools/baseball/power-rankings/%28year%29/2008/%28tab%29/0|title=NCSA Collegiate Power Rankings|accessdate=2009-07-21|publisher=National Collegiate Scouting Association}} rate colleges and universities comprehensively based on student-athlete graduation rates, academic strength and athletic prowess of the university. The institutions posted in the 2007 Power Rankings represent less than 6% of colleges and universities across the nation.{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/08-20-2007/0004648309&EDATE=|title=National Collegiate Scouting Association Announces 2007 Collegiate Power Rankings|date=2007-08-20|accessdate=2008-03-11|publisher=National Collegiate Scouting Association}} UCSD placed 4th on the overall ranking list, trailing behind [[Williams College]], [[Amherst College]], and [[Duke University]], and first on the Division II list. ==People== {{Main|List of University of California, San Diego people}} ===Faculty=== The university employs 1,205 faculty members, including six [[Nobel Prize|Nobel Laureates]], four [[MacArthur Fellows Program|MacArthur fellows]], three [[National Medal of Science]] laureates, and two [[Fields Medal|Fields medalists]]. UCSD faculty also include 146 [[John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation|Guggenheim Fellows]]. UCSD ranks sixth in the nation in terms of [[United States National Academy of Sciences]] membership. UCSD has a total of [[List of Nobel laureates by university affiliation|20 Nobel Laureates affiliated with it]]. === Alumni === {{See also|UCSD Alumni Association}} Over 130,000 [[alumni]] are associated with UCSD.{{cite web|url=http://alumni.ucsd.edu/aboutus/board.htm |title=UCSD Alumni Association: Board of Directors |publisher=Alumni.ucsd.edu |date= |accessdate=2009-07-16}} Notable alumni include [[Bill Atkinson]] and [[Bud Tribble]], members of the [[Apple Macintosh]] development team; biotechnology pioneers [[David Goeddel]] and [[Craig Venter]], and [[Nobel Prize]] winners [[Bruce Beutler]] (Physiology or Medicine), and [[Susumu Tonegawa]], recognized for his work in [[immunology]]. [[Eleanor Mariano]], the first Filipino-American to reach the rank of [[Rear Admiral]] in the [[United States Navy]] and first female director of the [[White House Medical Unit]], received her BS in Biology cum laude in 1977. A number of [[science fiction]] authors including [[Gregory Benford]], [[David Brin]] and [[Kim Stanley Robinson]] earned PhDs at UCSD; cartoon animation producer [[Mike Judge]] is also an alum.{{cite web|url=http://alumni.ucsd.edu/prominent/index.htm|title=Prominent Alumni|work=UCSD Alumni Association|publisher=University of California, San Diego|accessdate=2009-07-30}} [[Robert Buckley]], who stars as Clay on The CW television show ''[[One Tree Hill (TV series)|One Tree Hill]]'' graduated from UCSD with a degree in Economics. ''[[The Kite Runner]]'''s [[Khaled Hosseini]] is also a UCSD alum as well as [[Dileep Rao]], one of the stars of the hit blockbuster movies ''[[Avatar (2009 film)|Avatar]]'' and ''[[Inception]]''. Rao spoke at the 2010 Convocation Dinner as he kicked off UCSD's 50th Anniversary Celebration. The three members of the popular Asian American filmmaking group [[Wong Fu Productions]], Ted Fu, Phillip Wang, and Wesley Chan all graduated from UCSD as well. [[Anna Marie Caballero]] is a former member of the [[California State Assembly]] and had previously served as the Mayor and Council member of [[Salinas, California]].
